questions.text: Which of the following is the causative organism of vulval warts?
questions.solution:
The causative agent of vulval warts is the human papillomavirus (HPV).

Genital warts/venereal warts/condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region and vulva. The lesions may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favoured by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.

HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo, as shown below.

The diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The abnormal areas of the skin retain the blue dye. These areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.

The given image below shows condyloma acuminata:

 

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 1,2,3,4
  • Common warts (verruca vulgaris, plantar wart)
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   

 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text: A young woman presented with the following lesion on her vulva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of condyloma acuminata that shows cauliflower-like masses of tissue on and around the female anogenital region. 

Condyloma acuminatum is an epidermal manifestation of the human papillomavirus (HPV). 

HPV is transmitted through contact with infected skin or mucosa. The virus invades the cells of the epidermal basal layer through microabrasions. However, anogenital HPV infection is almost always acquired through sexual contact. 

Warts are not required for transmission but are highly infectious because of their high viral load.

Option B: The image given below shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with a characteristic dimple at the centre. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum caused by the pox virus.

Option C: The image given below shows firm papules with a rough horny surface. These are seen in verruca vulgaris caused by the human papillomavirus type 2.

Option D: The image given below shows condyloma lata which is the characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum.

questions.text: A sexually active woman presents with cauliflower-like lesions on the vulva. The biopsy of the lesion is taken and histopathology reveals the following picture. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows koilocytes, a characteristic feature of infection with human papillomavirus (HPV).

Other features that can also be seen on histology are:

  • Perinuclear halo
  • Multinucleation
  • Orangeophilic cytoplasm
  • Acanthosis
  • Chronic inflammatory infiltrate

Option A: Henderson-Paterson bodies are seen in molluscum contagiosum, caused by poxvirus.

Option C and D: Cowdry bodies are seen in herpes infection.

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Bacteria  Inclusion bodies 
Granuloma inguinale, Klebsiella granulomatis Donovan bodies
Psittacosis, Chlamydia psittacci  Levinthal-Cole-Lille bodies (LCL bodies)
Trachoma, Chlamydia trachomatis Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies
Lymphogranuloma venereum, Chlamydia trachomatis Miyagawa’s granulocorpusles
Diphtheria, Corynebacterium diptheriae Babes-Ernst granules

 

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

  • Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies
Disease/Virus Inclusion bodies
Rabies Negri bodies
Vaccinia, variola (smallpox) Guarnieri bodies
Variola (smallpox) Paschen bodies
Molluscum contagiosum Henderson-Patterson bodies
Fowlpox Bollinger bodies
  • Intra-nuclear Inclusion Bodies 
  Inclusion bodies  Disease/Virus
Cowdry type A Lipschutz inclusions Herpes Virus
Torres bodies Yellow fever
Cowdry type B Basophilic inclusions Adenovirus
Acidophilic inclusions Poliovirus
  • Both Intra-nuclear and Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies 
Disease/Virus  Inclusion bodies 
Measles Virus Warthin-Finkedly giant cells
Cytomegalovirus Owl-eye inclusions (basophilic, predominantly intra-nuclear, small granular intracytoplasmic inclusions are found)

 

3. Inclusion Bodies in Parasitic Infections 

Disease/Parasite Inclusion bodies 
Trypanosomiasis Morula cells with IgM Deposits
Kala-azar Leishman-Donovan Bodies

 

4. Miscellaneous Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Location Inclusion bodies 
Ovarian cortex Walthard Inclusions
Spherical globules surrounded by granulosa cells in the ovary Call-Exner bodies
Parkinsonism, Lewy body dementia  Lewy Bodies
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis  Bunina bodies
Multiple Myeloma Russell Bodies

questions.text: Which of the following serotypes are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus?
questions.solution:
Serotypes 16 and 18 are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus (HPV). It is called Cervarix. Cervarix is given at 0, 1 and 6 months.

Gardasil/Silgard is the quadrivalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16 and 18 and is given at 0, 2 and 6 months.

Gardasil 9 is the nonavalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. In 2020 it has received an expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and head and neck cancers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option for a patient with genital warts?
questions.solution:
Genital warts are treated by a local application of 25% trichloracetic acid + 5% fluorouracil.

Treatment of genital warts includes the local application of:

  • Podophyllin 25% in alcohol/podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin daily for 4 days (or)
  • 25% trichloracetic acid +5% fluorouracil daily for 4 days

If this fails, the following treatment is given:

  • Interferon ointment/cream or intralesional interferon injection 
  • Imiquimod cream thrice a week for 4 months

If medical treatment fails then cryosurgery, diathermy or laser removal is done.

questions.text: A sexually active woman who presented with an ulcer over the vulva was diagnosed with primary syphilis. What is the characteristic feature associated with this condition?

choices.text: Non suppurative, tender, and enlarged nodes
Firm, shotty, and painless nodes that do not suppurate
Painful, tender, and matted nodes forming an abscess
Painful, inflamed, necrotic nodes developing a chronic sinus

questions.solution:
The characteristic feature associated with primary syphilis is firm, shotty, painless nodes that do not suppurate.

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the motile spirochete, Treponema pallidum. In primary syphilis, the classical lesion i.e.,  chancre appears within 9–90 days from the first exposure.

The macular lesion becomes papular and then ulcerates. The ulcer(s) is painless and firm, with a punched out base and rolled edges. If left unattended, these heal within 3–9 weeks. It is accompanied by painless ingui­nal discrete lymphadenopathy.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman known to have syphilis presented with the following lesions over the vulva. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The given image shows condyloma lata, a classic finding of secondary syphilis.

Multiple moist well-demarcated papules and plaques are seen in condyloma lata. They are highly contagious, exophytic broad excrescences that ulcer­ate and are commonly seen on the vulva, perianal area and upper thighs.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A sexually active patient was diagnosed with lymphogranuloma venereum. What is the causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The causative agent for lymphogranuloma venereum is Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes L1/L2/L3). Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted disease that causes genital ulcers.

It has the following three stages of infection: 

Stage of LGV Characteristic features 
Primary stage
  • Painless genital ulcer
  • Papules
  • Lymphangitis
Secondary stage
  • Painful unilateral/bilateral lymphadenopathy 
  • Buboes
  • Groove sign
Late stage
  • Stricture formation
  • Fibrosis and fistulae of the anogenital region

Chlamydia trachomatis is a small gram-negative bacte­rium and an obligate intracellular parasite that appears as an intracytoplasmic inclusion body. The gram stain of the cervical smear would show leucocytes but no organisms. Hence, selective culture media like the McCoy cells culture is used to isolate the organism.

The slide given below is an iodine-stained smear prepared from the patient's endocervical sample. It shows inclusion bodies characteristic of Chlamydia trachomatis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old sexually active man comes to the STD clinic with a painful genital ulcer. On examination, the ulcer and the right inguinal lymph nodes were tender. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi which is a gram-negative anaerobe.

Chancroid is symptomatic in men. Both ulcer and lymphadenopathy are painful. Lymphadenopathy in chancroid is either unilateral or bilateral. Chancroid is generally asymptomatic in women but sometimes presents as painful lymphadenopathy.

The image below shows a chancroid ulcer with purulent and haemorrhagic discharge. It has a non-indurated, erythematous base.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

questions.text: A sexually active man presents with complaints of painful swelling over the inguinal region. He also gives a history of a painless genital ulcer that resolved spontaneously. On examination,  groove sign is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The pathognomic groove sign of Greenblatt is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1, L2, L3).

This image shows groove sign which is seen in ⅓ of the cases in the secondary stage of LGV. It refers to the depression between the enlarged femoral and inguinal lymph nodes on either side of the inguinal ligament. 

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted disease that causes genital ulcers. It has the following three stages of infection: 

Stage of LGV Characteristic features 
Primary stage
  • Painless genital ulcer
  • Papules
  • Lymphangitis
Secondary stage
  • Painful unilateral/bilateral lymphadenopathy 
  • Buboes
  • Groove sign
Late stage
  • Stricture formation
  • Fibrosis and fistulae of the anogenital region

questions.text: A 20-year-old female sex worker presents with complaints of constipation and blood in stools for 3 months. On DRE, a circumferential constriction is felt beyond which the finger cannot be advanced. Which of the following is a probable cause for this complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rectal stricture which is a complication of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). 

LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes L1/L2/L3). Rectal involvement is commonly seen in women as the primary disease often goes unnoticed and untreated. Anorectal involvement causes proctocolitis and causes rectal strictures. This occurs due to the contigu­ous spread of the primary infection from the perirectal nodes leading to scar tissue formation.

The complications of lymphogranuloma venereum include:

  • Rectal stricture formation may lead to:
    • Intestinal obstruction
    • Rectovaginal fistulae
  • Proctitis
  • Vulvar cancer.

questions.text: What is the causative agent for granuloma inguinale?
questions.solution:
The causative agent for granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is Calym­matobacterium granulomatis. It is now called Klebsiella granulomatis and is a gram-negative bacillus causing chronic ulcerative infection of the vulva.

It is highly contagious and transmitted through repeated sexual or non-sexual contact. The incubation period is 1-12 weeks.

Clinical features:

It begins as a painless nodule which later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers that tend to coalesce; the vulva is progressively destroyed, and minimal adenopathy may occur. 

Diagnosis: 

Microscopic examination of smears from the lesion/ biopsy specimens reveals pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies and clusters of bacteria with a bipolar (safety pin) appearance. Blue-black stained organisms are seen in the cytoplasm of mononuclear cells. 

Management:

Azithromycin 1 g orally once per week or 500 mg daily for at least 3 weeks and until all lesions have completely healed.

The given image below shows the donovanosis in a female patient with a beefy red ulcer:

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presented with multiple beefy-red ulcers over the labia. Microscopic examination of smear from the lesion showed intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies and gram-negative bacteria having a safety pin appearance. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granuloma inguinale which is caused by a gram-negative bacteria, Klebsiella granulomatis.

Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce and bleed easily on contact. If secondarily infected, they may become painful. The ulcers heal by fibrosis, which can result in scarring resembling keloids.

The lymph nodes are usually uninvolved but can become enlarged. New lesions can appear along the lymphatic drainage channels.

The gross image below shows granuloma inguinale of the cervix with a beefy red appearance of the hypervascular intravaginal tissues. 

The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance.

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
